title: 114_hr1105
content: The "Death Tax Repeal Act of 2015" aims to repeal estate and generation-skipping transfer taxes under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This Act includes a new section titled "SEC. 2210. TERMINATION." The Death Tax Repeal Act of 2015 includes a new section titled "SEC. 2210. TERMINATION" which exempts estates of decedents dying after the enactment date from certain provisions. The Death Tax Repeal Act of 2015 exempts generation-skipping transfers after its enactment date. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code, and the effective date applies to decedents' estates and transfers after the Act's enactment. SEC. 3. MODIFICATIONS OF GIFT TAX. Amends the computation of gift tax under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The tax imposed for each calendar year is based on the aggregate sum of taxable gifts. The tentative tax is calculated based on different income brackets, with varying percentages and fixed amounts for each bracket. For incomes over $100,000, the tax rates are as follows: $38,800 plus 32% of the excess over $150,000 for incomes between $150,000 and $250,000, $70,800 plus 34% of the excess over $250,000 for incomes between $250,000 and $500,000, and $155,800 plus 35% of the excess over $500,000 for incomes over $500,000. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 has been amended to include new provisions regarding the treatment of certain transfers in trust and lifetime gift exemption. Transfers in trust will be treated as taxable gifts unless the trust is wholly owned by the donor or the donor's spouse. The lifetime gift exemption amount is now determined based on a tentative tax computed at $5,000,000. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 has been amended to include new provisions regarding the treatment of certain transfers in trust and lifetime gift exemption. The lifetime gift exemption amount is now determined based on a tentative tax computed at $5,000,000, with provisions for inflation adjustment. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 has been amended to include new provisions regarding the treatment of certain transfers in trust and lifetime gift exemption. The lifetime gift exemption amount is now determined based on a tentative tax computed at $5,000,000, with provisions for inflation adjustment. Amendments have been made to section 2505, including changes to the heading and table of sections for subchapter A of chapter 12. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 has been amended to include new provisions related to gift tax credits and effective dates for gifts made after the enactment of the Act. A transition rule is also established for the application of certain sections of the Code. According to section 2504(b) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, the year in which this Act is enacted will be considered as the preceding calendar period. The budgetary effects of this Act will not be included in the PAYGO scorecard as per the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010.
